Award.AwardTitle: Analysis of Large Amplitude, Short Duration Control Forces for Guiding Underactuated Mechanical Systems into Safe Operating Regions

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
In a fully actuated mechanical system, an independent control force is available for each degree of freedom. Systems with fewer independent controls than degrees-of-freedom are called "underactuated." Many important systems are naturally of this class, including certain types of missiles, satellites, underwater vehicles, and bipedal robots. As might be expected from the shortage of control inputs, underactuated systems are challenging to stabilize and to steer. This project improves upon existing approaches by using large-amplitude, short-duration control forces -- called impulsive forces -- to expand the region of attraction of the system. The region of attraction is the set of initial configurations and velocities from which the system will be able to reach its desired operating point. If the system ever leaves its region of attraction, it will depart from its desired behavior, corresponding to, for example, the loss of control of a missile or spacecraft. Expanding the region of attraction means safer operation, since the system can tolerate upsets due to large disturbance forces or unexpected initial conditions. A major new contribution of this project will be to bridge the gap between purely theoretical studies and practical applications, through careful experimental validation on widely accepted benchmark test bed systems.

Dynamical systems are continuously subjected to disturbances and their ability to reject them largely depend on the stability property of their equilibrium configurations. This research will enlarge the region of stable operation of underactuated dynamical systems and reduce the incidence of unstable behavior, behavior that typically has negative consequences. The region of stable operation will be enlarged by application of impulsive forces, which will be included in the set of admissible control inputs. In this project, impulsive control will be implemented using high-gain feedback over short intervals of time and mathematical tools such as singular perturbation methods will be used to analyze and design the high-gain feedback systems. The implementation of high-gain feedback will require the use of very fast observers to estimate the unmeasured velocities. To this end, high-gain observers will be designed and analyzed via multi-time-scale singular perturbation methods. There are many challenging technical issues that need to be solved to make such designs feasible. This includes the development of efficient algorithms that can transfer the system configuration from outside the region of stable operation to inside the region, using a single application or multiple applications of impulsive inputs. The developed algorithms will be tested experimentally on simple underactuated systems; but the methods will be applicable to more complex problems such as orbital transfer of satellites, rapid maneuvering of missiles and underwater vehicles, and active prosthetic devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Underactuated mechanical systems are challenging to control because they have fewer control inputs than the number of their generalized coordinates. This research focused on problems of stabilization of both equilibrium points and periodic orbits. The control designs were verified through simulations as well as through experiments. The intellectual merit of the research is summarized with the help of the technical contributions below.

We first investigated the problem of stabilizing equilibria of underactuated systems. The ability of the system to remain stable in the presence of disturbances depends on the size of the region of attraction of the stabilized equilibrium. The sum-of-squares and trajectory reversing methods were combined to generate a large estimate of the region of attraction. This estimate was then effectively enlarged by applying the Impulse Manifold Method (IMM) to stabilize equilibria from points lying outside the estimated region of attraction. Simulation were carried out for a three degree-of-freedom tiptoebot and experimental validation was performed on a two degree-of-freedom pendubot. 

Second, we investigated the control the underactuated inertia-wheel pendulum (IWP) using impulsive inputs only. When subjected to impulsive inputs, the dynamics of the IWP can be described by algebraic equations. Optimal sequences of inputs were designed to achieve rest-to-rest maneuvers and the results were applied to the swing-up control problem.

The problem of juggling a devil-stick using solely impulsive inputs was investigated next. Impulsive forces were applied to the stick intermittently and the impulse of the force and its point of application were modeled as inputs to the system. A dead-beat design for one of the inputs simplified the control problem and results in a discrete linear time invariant system. To achieve symmetric juggling, linear quadratic regulator (LQR) and model predictive control (MPC) based designs were proposed and validated through simulations.

A repetitive motion is described by closed orbits; therefore, stabilization of closed orbits is important for many applications such as bipedal walking and steady swimming. We investigated the problem of energy-based orbital stabilization using continuous inputs and intermittent impulsive braking. The orbit is a manifold where the active generalized coordinates are fixed and the total mechanical energy of the system is equal to some desired value. Simulation and experimental results were provided for the tiptoebot and the rotary pendulum, respectively.

Finally, the problem of orbital stabilization using virtual holonomic constraints (VHC) was studied. VHCs were enforced using a continuous controller which guarantees existence of closed orbits. A Poincare section was constructed on the desired orbit and the orbit was stabilized using impulsive inputs which were applied intermittently when the system trajectory cross the Poincare section. This approach to orbital stabilization, which we refer to as the Impulse Controlled Poincare Map (ICPM) approach is general, and has lower complexity and computational cost than control designs proposed earlier.

In addition to the scientific and technological contributions, the project had broad impact through integration and research and education and potential application of the results to other dynamical systems. The project funded a graduate student who completed his PhD degree and joined the workforce. Findings of the research have been integrated into a graduate course in Dynamics. The results of the research will find a wide range of applications from swimming and legged locomotion to control of active prosthetic devices and non-prehensile manipulation.
